perturbation.original_text: (a) The Term of this Agreement (the “Term”) shall commence on the Effective Date listed above and continue for twenty (20) years, unless sooner terminated as provided in Section 7(b).
perturbation.changed_text:
(a) The Term of this Agreement (the “Term”) shall commence on the Effective Date listed above and continue for twenty (20) years, unless sooner terminated as provided in Section 7(b).

Notwithstanding the foregoing, this agreement can be terminated by the Licensor with 30 days written notice, if the Licensee does not meet the minimum revenue thresholds as defined and outlined in Schedule B. Failure to meet these thresholds constitutes a material breach, allowing for immediate termination without the cure period outlined in 7(b).
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction in the termination clause. Section 7(a) establishes a 20-year term, and 7(b) outlines conditions for termination. However, the added text allows the Licensor to terminate the agreement under different conditions (failure to meet revenue thresholds in Schedule B) with only 30 days notice and immediate effect, overriding the standard cure period in 7(b). This creates uncertainty about which termination terms apply, especially regarding the required notice period and opportunity to cure the alleged breach. This could lead to disputes over whether the termination was valid.

perturbation.original_text: (b) This Agreement may be terminated at any time by either party, effective immediately upon written notice, if the other party: (i) becomes insolvent; (ii) files a petition in bankruptcy; or (iii) makes an assignment for the benefit of its creditors. Either party may terminate this Agreement upon written notice if the other party materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure such breach within thirty (30) days after the date that it receives written notice of such breach from the non-breaching party.
perturbation.changed_text: (b) This Agreement may be terminated at any time by either party, effective immediately upon written notice, if the other party: (i) becomes insolvent; (ii) files a petition in bankruptcy; or (iii) makes an assignment for the benefit of its creditors. Licensee only may terminate this Agreement upon written notice if the other party materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure such breach within thirty (30) days after the date that it receives written notice of such breach from the non-breaching party. In the event of a material breach by the licensee, the licensor can terminate the agreement within 5 days, without right to cure.
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation introduces a contradiction by creating asymmetric termination rights. Initially, either party can terminate for material breach with a 30-day cure period. The modified text restricts the Licensor's right to terminate without providing a 30-day cure period to the licensee. This inconsistency creates ambiguity and potential disputes regarding the conditions and procedures for termination, especially if the Licensor attempts to terminate without allowing the Licensee to cure the breach. The clause initially allowed either party to terminate with a 30 day window, but now has different conditions for termination depending on which party is breaching the agreement.

perturbation.original_text: (h) Assignment. Neither party may assign its rights, duties or obligations under this Agreement to any third party in whole or in part, without the other party’s prior written consent, except that (i) Licensee may assign its rights and obligations to this Agreement to any of its Affiliate or subsidiaries with the prior written consent of the Licensor, and (ii) Licensor may assign its rights and obligations in this Agreement to its Affiliates or subsidiaries and either party may assign this Agreement in its entirety to any purchaser of all or substantially all of its business or assets pertaining to the line of business to which this Agreement relates or to any Affiliate of the party without the other party’s approval. This Agreement will be binding upon, and inure to the benefit of, the respective permitted assignees, transferees and successors of each of the parties.
perturbation.changed_text: (h) Assignment. Neither party may assign its rights, duties or obligations under this Agreement to any third party in whole or in part, without the other party’s prior written consent, except that (i) Licensee may assign its rights and obligations to this Agreement to any of its Affiliate or subsidiaries with the prior written consent of the Licensor, and (ii) Licensor may assign its rights and obligations in this Agreement to its Affiliates or subsidiaries and either party may assign this Agreement in its entirety to any purchaser of all or substantially all of its business or assets pertaining to the line of business to which this Agreement relates or to any Affiliate of the party without the other party’s approval. Notwithstanding the above, the Licensor can automatically assign this agreement to any entity controlled by Bruno Wu without prior approval. This Agreement will be binding upon, and inure to the benefit of, the respective permitted assignees, transferees and successors of each of the parties.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates a contradiction within the assignment clause. Initially, the clause states that neither party can assign the agreement without the other party's written consent, except for assignments to affiliates or in cases of a sale of business/assets. The added text allows the Licensor to automatically assign the agreement to any entity controlled by Bruno Wu without prior approval. This contradicts the initial requirement of obtaining the other party's (Licensee's) consent for assignments, creating uncertainty and potential disputes about the validity of assignments made under this condition. This can lead to conflict as it is creating another exception that is not aligned with the initial assignment clause.
